items.title: slow/missing DNS server has huge effect on results
items.body:
If I add a non-existent DNS `nameserver` to the top of `/etc/resolv.conf` (e.g. 192.168.8.254), the resulting DNS slowness has a huge effect on the download/upload speeds.  I read that other people found the same DNS problems (#638, #381, #117) over the past five years.  I would hope that the script could be modified to do the DNS lookups first, before the timing loop, so that the server URLs would use IP addresses instead of host names and not require any DNS lookup?  The [Ookla CLI client](https://www.speedtest.net/apps/cli) doesn't have this problem.

Here's a (correct) result without the bogus DNS server:

`# bin/speedtest-cli_2.1.2 --server 16610      `                                                                             
`Download: 47.15 Mbit/s       `                                                                                             
`Upload: 11.53 Mbit/s`

I add the bogus DNS server to the top of `/etc/resolv.conf` and things go very wrong:
                                                        
`# bin/speedtest-cli_2.1.2 --server 16610     `                                                                                 
`Download: 2.17 Mbit/s        `                                                                                             
`Upload: 2.51 Mbit/s `

The reason I found this, is that I have two Internet connections from two providers, with two DNS `nameserver` lines in my `/etc/resolv.conf` file, and the first provider went down last night and caused the `speedtest` results from the other provider to go wrong.  DNS look-up delays should not be part of the output results.

items.title: Upload speed error capped at 3.99 Mbps?
items.body:
On a wired (1Gbps) Ubuntu box on a 200/100 connection, roughly 202 Mbps download is consistently reported, but upload only reports as 3.98 Mbps or similar. Never reaching 4 Mbps. 

I confirmed the actual upload is much better by testing from wireless machines on the same network and saw upload results of ~80 Mbps. 

Testing was then performed from the Ubuntu wired box with Ookla's speedtest binaries, resulting in 108 Mbps result. 

Any idea what might be going on here?

speedtest-cli is awesome and very helpful, I'd like to contribute where I can, but sorry that I'm not a Python developer, so just fire an issue here first, and will dig deeper to see if I have a chance to send a pull request to implement it. 
(if the suggestion is accepted, of course)

Speedtest released official command line tool recently: https://www.speedtest.net/apps/cli

There is a parameter very useful to me: `-L, --servers  List nearest servers`, and below is its output:

```
$ speedtest -L
Closest servers:

    ID  Name                           Location             Country

I am running a crontab for my shell script. This script is doing a speedtest. When the crontab is calling my Shell script then the upload is locking to 3 Mbit. When I call the script by myself then the Upload is about 10-15 Mbit.

Here is the Shellscript:
`#!/bin/bash
echo Starting Speedtest...
LINK=$(speedtest --secure --share | sed -nr 's/Share results: http\s*//p')
LINK=https$LINK
echo Speedtest Results: $LINK
date=$(date +%F)
HOUR=$(date +%H)
if [ -d "/var/www/html/img/speedtest/"$date ]; then
        echo Verzeichnis besteht
else
        echo Verzeichnis wird erstellt
        sudo mkdir /var/www/html/img/speedtest/$date && sudo cp /var/www/speedtest/index.php /var/www/html/img/speedtest/$date
fi
cd /var/www/html/img/speedtest/$date
sudo wget $LINK -O $HOUR.png
echo Finished saving File.`

And here is my cronjob
`5 * * * * /var/www/speedtest/speed.sh`

Here the Speedtest executed by me in cli as .png file:

items.title: Seems like slow DNS resolution provides slow results
items.body:
Hello,

Using latest speedtest-cli from today.

I had a network speed issues on a server. I thought it looked like DNS resolution resolution delay, but first, I tried a speedtest-cli, showing aweful speeds (around 3mbps for about 100 expected). So I ditched the DNS resolution hypothesis.

After 20 minutes or fiddling around, I tried changing the DNS which were pretty bad ones, and suddently all issues were resolved. -even the speedtest bandwidth test-

Conclusion: It seems like the speetest-cli test doesn't handle the case where DNS resolution is slow, and I would also think that the DNS resolution delay is included in the overall upload and download speedtest which in my opinion, should not be.

The issue might be hard to reproduce (getting slow DNS servers isn't easy...), but I would suggest reviewing the code with in mind that the DNS resolution time shouldn't be part of the speed result. Fix might be pretty easy.

Maybe I'm not right about how it works currently, I just wanted to let you know this, just in case. I remain available if I can help on this one. (I know Bash, and I got sysadmin knowlege, if it can be any use).

Best regards

I tested a server with a RTT of 3.757 ms and had a downlad speed of 557.26 Mbit/s. Mathematically, with a window size of max 64KB and and RTT of 3.757, I should reach at best 139.55 Mbit/sec in a single TCP connection.

Hi, Relateive;ly new to python scripts, so bare with. 

Have used speedtest-cli before. I have edited the script so it will insert the values into a sql table as below, however having an issue with one of the inserts. It will insert ping, and download ok, however the upload is always 2.74 or 2.75 for example, but ONLY when run from a crontab.. very wierd. 

If I run the python script from cli it will insert values fine. 

```
import os

import re

import subprocess

import time

import mysql.connector
from mysql.connector import Error
from mysql.connector import errorcode


print "----------------------------------"
print 'Started: {} {}'.format(time.strftime('%d/%m/%y %H:%M:%S'), "")

response = subprocess.Popen('speedtest-cli --simple', shell=True, stdout=subprocess.PIPE).stdout.read()



ping = re.findall('Ping:\s(.*?)\s', response, re.MULTILINE)

download = re.findall('Download:\s(.*?)\s', response, re.MULTILINE)

upload = re.findall('Upload:\s(.*?)\s', response, re.MULTILINE)



ping[0] = ping[0].replace(',', '.')

download[0] = download[0].replace(',', '.')

upload[0] = upload[0].replace(',', '.')



try:

    if os.stat('/var/www/html/speed/log.txt').st_size == 0:

        print 'Date,Time,Ping (ms),Download (Mbit/s),Upload (Mbit/s)'

except:

    pass



print 'PING: {}, DOWN: {}, UP: {}'.format(ping[0], download[0], upload[0])



try:
   connection = mysql.connector.connect(host='localhost',
                             database='DB',
                             user='USER',
                             password='PASS')

   sql_insert_query = ("""INSERT INTO speedtest(ping, download, upload) VALUES (%s,%s,%s)""", (ping[0], download[0], upload[0]))

   cursor = connection.cursor()
   result  = cursor.execute(*sql_insert_query)
   connection.commit()
   print ("Insert success into speedtest tbl")

except mysql.connector.Error as error :
    connection.rollback() #rollback if any exception occured
    print("Failed inserting record into speedtest table {}".format(error))

finally:
    #closing database connection.
    if(connection.is_connected()):
        cursor.close()
        connection.close()
        print("MySQL conn closed")


print 'Finished: {} {}'.format(time.strftime('%d/%m/%y %H:%M:%S'), "")
```

items.title: Inconsistent speeds: RESOLVED
items.body:
Just wanted to let everyone know that I found a resolution to actual inconsistent speeds (NOT PING/LATENCY).

I ran this program on 3 different devices and 3 different versions of python3:
[Aries] (RaspberryPi 3 Model B+): Python3 Version = Python 3.4.2 --> Runs perfect speedtests with correct results (Correct Download, Correct Upload)
[Taurus] (RaspberryPi 3 Model B+): Python3 Version = Python 3.7.3 --> Runs imperfect speedtests with incorrect results (Correct Download, Max ~3Mbps Upload)
[Leo] (Ubuntu Custom Machine): Python3 Version = Python 3.6.8 --> Runs imperfect speedtests with incorrect results (Correct-ish Download, Max ~3Mbps Upload)

I also ran it with my two WSL machines, one at home and one at work, and they both report incorrect speeds (one on python3 3.5.2 and one on python3 3.6.8).

I then went to attempt to research the issue and notably found that different python versions can report different results.

I attempted to uninstall and reinstall the program with no luck, and attempted upgrading my python3 version also with no luck.

Finally, I somehow (I forget how I found it, probably when I was reinstalling it) found the path of the program (/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/speedtest.py) and forced it to just use python (2.7.15rc1) and it worked!

Command: python /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/speedtest.py

items.title: Proxy compatibility seems broken
items.body:
Hi!

Problem : I'm unable to get speedtest-cli to work behing a proxy.

Here's what I did :


### Proxy variable declaration : 
```
export http_proxy=http://10.1.1.1:8080
export https_proxy=http://10.1.1.1:8080
```

### Speedtest-cli give an error :
```
[root@perfsonar speedtest-cli]# speedtest-cli
Retrieving speedtest.net configuration...
Cannot retrieve speedtest configuration
ERROR: <urlopen error [SSL: UNKNOWN_PROTOCOL] unknown protocol (_ssl.c:618)>
```

### Validate that the proxy settings are in the speedtest-cli environement :

``` 
speedtest-cli &
pgrep speedtest-cli
cat /proc/`pgrep speedtest-cli`/environ
```

**http_proxy=http://10.120.138.22:8080**rootMAIL=/var/spool/mail/lbsoullierePATH=/usr/local/sbin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/binPWD=/home/lbsoulliere/speedtest-cliDJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=esmond.settingsLANG=en_US.UTF-8**https_proxy=http://10.120.138.22:8080**

### Packet capture to make sure the proxy is used :
tcpdump -i eno1 -s 0 -w spdt.pcap

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30626084/60128229-22528a00-9760-11e9-8124-c4814c9cca58.png)
